Posts.Content: Hi Sorry you have this worry, it is indeed all you need. Far from being a health risk it may well reduce the number of mammos you need to have. Welcome progress if the study is a success. I was also recalled from screening and because of the uncertainty of what they were dealing with between mammos, repeat, magnified, guided biopsy and check I counted seven in one day. I have had my surgery and reconstruction and apart from wobbling a bit this week am none the worse for my ordeal. On that score I have had some great advice on here for which I will be eternally grateful. Wishing you well for your appointment
Posts.Title: Tomosynthesis Mammography is it safe?

Posts.Content: So pleased to hear your good news, thank you for coming back with an update. Wishing you well for the future.
Posts.Title: Tomosynthesis Mammography is it safe?

Posts.Content: Wendy Best piece of advice I got was to take in a soft towel as the hospital ones tend to be very rough. I took in a notebook and pen to record my feelings, thankful that I did as I'd been told my post op stay would be two to three days and it ended up being seven. My hospital preferred the drains to be under 40mls before allowing you home but removed them after seven days regardless to avoid infection, this was fine by me. Between my dog and young grandchildren I would have been terrified of it being pulled out. I never did get to listen to my ipod or read my book as there was plenty of conversations going on in the ward. Visitors/staff ate my sweets. Wishing you all the best, hope you are as pleased with your reconstruction as I was.
Posts.Title: What to take with me into hospital for MX & Lymph node clearance ...

Posts.Content: Goals1, welcome onboard although I am sorry you find yourself here with this concern.  I can only reiterate all that Lulu34 has said, really sound advice.  Hopefully it wont be too long before your doctor has the chance to review your previous images and he can reassure you. Six months would have been way too long for me to be worrying, although I did find myself in the position of wondering if I might have been overdiagnosed, not a nice place to be. I put up a general blog at the weekend but therein are some facts of what my microcalcifications turned out to be.
Posts.Title: findings

Posts.Content: WOW!! Dorothee well done you. Two Race for Life's in as many weeks. Have a safe and enjoyable trip albeit tinged with sadness. My thoughts will be with you all
Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: Dorothee, Those of us who were around this time last year will not forget Annabel. You have some really good suggestions here already and I'm not half as good with words as you are but would like to say thank you and that something for the children would be a wonderful legacy for Annabel. Could be anything from a new toy to a holiday. Is it possible that Annabel's Angels could grow big enough to provide a caravan or two. Just a thought........... Another thing I didn't see in previous posts, apologies if I missed it, access to a specially trained fitness instructor who is aware of what is and isn't good for us along this rocky road. I was lucky enough to have a pretty cotton drain bag, mini under arm pillow, sports bra and bra top provided for me. Ah, there is another expense, suppose the list is endless.......... front fastening pj's for post surgery - maybe a merchandising oportunity here? Think my mind is going to run away with me so best stop here. Well done to all Annabel's Angels. Huge comforting hugs for everyone
Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: Frances, Pretty sure I'm Amoena's best customer I have a few of their bras in a couple of styles that fit really well but do remember being disappointed in the fit of one but it was no trouble to return and I was refunded no questions asked. It's nearly four years for me now and in that time I've only ever bought one bra elsewhere even though I don't have a prosthesis My staple is their Valletta top, they are so comfortable dressed up or down, I've bought at least a dozen in different colours a over the years.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Bras

Posts.Content: Not sure I'm allowed to do this but having moved on a bit in my recovery I have two Amoena T-shirt bras with bilateral pockets in size 36B that I have no further use for.  Rather than recycle I thought they may be of use to someone in the community.  If you think these may be of any help to you please do not hesitate to get in touch. Love, hugs and sincere wishes to each and everyone who finds themselves members of this community.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Bras

Posts.Content: We're all able to spread awareness in our own way, we most likely do it everyday without thinking. I know those close to me are checking more and looking forward to their first routine screening. Yesterday I had an appointment in another town. Having a couple of special events coming up, I thought that I would have a browse around the shops on my own. Ah bliss! Having to settle on the next best thing on one gift, I found myself saying "it's ok, this will be fine, perhaps even better" Now this is something the old me (or is that just pc me) would never have done but I found myself going on to explain why. This genuinely lovely lady went on to ask loads of questions, which I was happy to answer. She said it really made her think. Having said how good I look, and discussing my skin care regime as she couldn't believe how old I was, I just know that she will recount this tale to her family and friends and most likely them to theirs and so the awareness is spread from real life experience. Biggest of hugs and best wishes to all of you still fighting your battle. For me, today is one year on from my first positive biopsy result. I've stepped off that rollercoaster and sitting on the swings. I know I've still got a few hurdles ahead but hopefully I'll clear them too. Jules x
Posts.Title: we can spread the word, it's good to talk

Posts.Content: I was also told that 7 days was the maximum time for drains to be insitu in order to avoid any risk of infection.  Although mine was running at almost 50ml when it was removed, this almost certainly decreased rapidly, as the seroma was drained of only 50ml 5 days later.  I needed to have some more drained the following week but was pleasantly surprised at how painless it was.
Posts.Title: New to this

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply Helen, guess it's not a common complaint so may just have to bite the bullet and get my GP to check it out. I already have a good deal of discomfort at the side of my reconstruction and was advised to use ibuprofen gel, which does help, so really didn't want to approach bcn about ribs. Not so sure I didn't rush into "yep that sounds great........." somedays I'm not aware I've had anything done but others I could replicate what you're saying. Hope you are well and continuing to enjoy life in the saddle.
Posts.Title: anyone experienced painful ribs post Mx?

Posts.Content: I did have problems with my ribs prior to surgery but now totally confused as to whether the pain is from my original injuries or as a result of of surgery.
Posts.Title: anyone experienced painful ribs post Mx?

Posts.Content: Helen, thanks for the update, I feel a tad better with my lot after reading this.  I always wondered why I was never offered expanders as it seemed to me that it would have been a means of achieving a much more equal size.  Now I can see that perhaps it's something my Consultant prefers to avoid, although I do remember him measuring up my back before me saying no way, so their preference may be LD flap.  I don't think though that silicone guarantees no rippling as at my last appointment I was told that all was well but he could feel some rippling and it might stay that way, not sure if this could be due to the strattice holding it in place. Sorry I was the worlds worst person for asking questions, went through it all with blinkers on. That said, it is underneath so I'm not aware of it unless I have a check.  Good luck with your decision and have a wonderful holiday.
Posts.Title: Implants and reconstruction options - the update

Posts.Content: I'm in Scotland and my results were given to me 12 days after surgery. If the Bedford is a general hospital, it is possible that the delay is due to the time slot that the Consultant holds his outpatient clinic as opposed to an overworked Pathology Department. You will most likely find that your results and any further treatment has already been discussed with the Multi Disciplinary Team. Unfortunately GP's can cause unnecessary angst in relaying to patients what they think should happen, ironic really as they initially work their way up through that area. I'll be thinking of you and hope you get the reults you are hoping for.
Posts.Title: How long have you had to wait between surgery and "specimen" results...

Posts.Content: Like many others we have travel insurance attached to our bank account. We have booked a trip to USA to visit family, I am now on yearly screening, so thinking I do not have to declare cancer.......... wondering if anyone has any experience or advice to share.
Posts.Title: dilemma, to declare or not?

Posts.Content: Wise words as always from our own little viking. From someone who has had a mastecotomy albeit with reconstruction, I would have done exactly the same as you. I do agree though that perhaps it is ourselves who lack the confidence. Like you, when I'm at the gym, it's the children I do not want to offend although I guess I also concern myself too much with what their parents might say if they were to get upset or start asking too many awkward questions. In truth they probably wouldn't take any notice. I once had a status on here were a lady had said to me that I shouldn't be concerned with offending anyone with my reconstruction, instead I should be proud that I had beaten a dreadful disease. Certainly another angle to look at things but I have to admit that despite the encouragement I recieved from here, still the first thing I do is look for a free cubicle.
Posts.Title: Relatively trivial query about swimming pool

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly, I can empathise with the guilty feeling, honestly it does get better in time. I was invited onto a trial in October but ran scared at the mention of osteoporosis as my mum suffered badly from this. My thoughts were that I was getting older and at risk, so why would I want to give it a helping hand. My consultant was lovely, when I said that I felt bad because really I should do it to help others, he said I had to do what was right for me and that it would make no difference to the care I would recieve. I have an appointment with him tomorrow for the first of my yearly mammos and I'm sure it won't even be mentioned. Bad person? Absolutely not! You had the courage to post about this and I'm sure there must be others who like me, found comfort in knowing they weren't the only one to decline an invitation. Although I can't offer any advise on chemo, I do wish you all the best on your ride on this rollercoaster. Have faith in your team, they do have your best interests at heart. Take care Jules xo
Posts.Title: Am i really awful?

Posts.Content: Flower, like you say this might not be relevant come Thursday, so best check with your BCN or those on this site once the alien is about to attack. In the meantime hope this helps - My Mx scar runs right across the centre and I've recently been complaining of the sensation of an itchy nipple. I ran this past my BCN who spoke with the Consultant - his advice was to use simple moisturiser and take antihistimines. I was already doing this as it was driving me mad. I came to the conclusion that this was perhaps some additional healing going on as the colour of my scar changed for the better over that time. Hope you manage to get some relief and that the aliens are kind to you.
Posts.Title: A Tickly Itchy Problem .........

Posts.Content: Sascha Rose, you're not boring. Don't go beating yourself up, that's what my breast care nusre told me when I was having a major wobble. We do all know you've been having a terrible time with treatment in Spain. I can only begin to imagine what you're going trough but just wanted to pop in and give you a huge but gentle hug to keep you going until others who are more knowledgable come to your rescue.
Posts.Title: Obstacle course

Posts.Content: Townfan, I'll second that but would add my own account in the hope that it is of some comfort at this time on a Sunday night. I had my op on a Friday and felt really great all that weekend but was the sickest I've ever been on the Monday. Symptoms were exactly as you've described and believe me if there was an olympic medal for vomiting I'd have made it to the podium. I was still in hospital at the time and the nursing staff and my breast care nurse assured me it was the effects of the anaesthetic. Well done for being there to support your wife on what can be a long and arduous journey Jules
Posts.Title: Reality sinking in

Posts.Content: So pleased that your results turned out to be much better than anticipated, hopefully that will be the same for the necrosis. I hope too, that your sternum lump is indeed a lipoma, I had one removed from my shoulder a few years ago but can clearly remember the feeling when the consultant said "it's propbably just fatty tissue". I would try not to worry too much about genetic testing for the time being. From my understanding it would be your girls who would be tested to establish if they carried the gene(s). I felt that we were being discouraged when I questioned the occurances in our family with my BCN, I am the 6th, so naturally my daughter, sister and her daughters were concerned. Your comment about the testing for women in Scotland was interesting, now I get why they say DCIS is not cancer. Up until now I kept thinking, if it's not cancer why am I having to have a Mx but couldn't bring myself to ask.
Posts.Title: Specimen results day, and BRCA question

Posts.Content: A year ago on updating my status to say that all was clear for another year I recieved a reply from Dreamthief indicating that I ought to post a brief message to the group, I'm guessing because statuses go by so quickly. So.........yesterday was year four check up and yes for a whole week before there were anxieties over the wait for the results from my mammogram. All was well and with my reconstruction still feeling fine, I don't need to see the Consultant for another year. During the long wait at the clinic some of us got talking and I was able to advise how much being part of this community helped me through my dark times. We all shared experiences and hugged as we left and will likely continue to be a support to each other. I've had an amazing four years and wouldn't have had it any other way, thanks to the virtual friends who supported me on this site and those who stayed with me as well as those I have met along the road I was forced to travel. Keeping you all close in thought and leaving some {{{huge comforting hugs}}} for when you need them most. Link to photographer's blog on how I tackled my negative body image has now been removed, happy though to discuss and share as appropriate.
Posts.Title: yearly update

Posts.Content: beevergirl, just caught this thread after the last response. I see that you had already brought up the subject of anniversary wobbles, thanks for duplicating for me. I had to laugh at the response you got to your name choice, it just reminded me of all the times I get caught out with folks laughing while I try to phathom out why. My choice really sounds naff to me now! I was nicknamed Jules at school, already taken, ok no worries, just add some numbers, nope my choices all taken. Panic! Yikes! head in a muddle, first thought in my head is that hubby in an attempt to comfort me says you'll always be 17 to me. Clare, that made me laugh too......maybe just as well I didn't need chemo, my surname translates as wind Thanks again girls Jules xo
Posts.Title: Naïve or a dingbat

Posts.Content: Caroline, If you have an appointment coming up soon you can ask to view your records then. If not, then write to the Health Records Manager at your hospital requesting either access and/or copies. You are entitled to this under the Data Protection Act 1998. For access someone will sit with you while you view them, you can do only this or you can just request copies to view at your leisure or you can do both. I'm glad I got copies of mine. Hope this helps
Posts.Title: i never saw results

Posts.Content: Hello Fiona I'm new to this so not sure I'm answering in the right place. You are a bit ahead of me, but thought it'd help to know you're not alone. I had a mastectomy and reconstruction in October and still have a little bit of my scar to heal. I had an allergic reaction to the paper stitching rather than an infection. My Consultant decided to leave the wound uncovered rather than replace the dressing, a bit of a nuisance at times but I'm sure helped in the long run. I also took care with moisturiser, getting as close to but avoiding the actual scar.
Posts.Title: Any suggestions Please!

Posts.Content: Well said tinkers. Amoena are suberb aren't they. I did find that post a bit off as I've had a reconstruction and wear bras with pockets. My breast care nurse had directed me to Amoena's sports bra to start wearing six weeks post surgery. Later on, I started going to the gym and couldn't find a suitable sports bra, most were racer back and I found them very difficult to get into, so head for a trusted comfortble one. None of my previous everyday bras were suitable, and I lost count of the number I tried, only to be disappointed in one way or another. I ordered a couple of different styles from Amoena to try and opted for the fit and comfort of Angelina. I would recommend this to anyone regardless of reconstruction or not, much better a bra with pockets that you feel good in than one without that leaves you feeling vulnerable. Would a rose by any other name smell so sweet.........of course it would
Posts.Title: bras for reconstruction

Posts.Content: Earlier today my breath was taken away with a shooting pain. I had to laugh when my friend asked if I was ok. I would have said "a pain just shot right through my boob to my nipple" except that technically I have neither. Tomorrow will be eight months since my Mx and reconstruction and I can honestly say that this is the first time I have experienced this. Has anyone else had these phantom feelings, you do hear of this happening with amputees but I'd never considered it being a possibility for me. Apologies, don't wish to scare any newbies but can't get this experience out of my head.

Posts.Title: phantom or coincidental pain

Posts.Content: Flower, just thought I would  pop in to say thank you for the update.  You seem to have been lost in your own thread.  You have come a long way and should be proud that you are now celebrating the positives.  I hope you are truely feeling much better about your journey and will have you in my thoughts and prayers as you continue through the minefield.
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Sue, I didn't come to the site until after getting the all clear from the clinic. I couldn't understand why I was so tearful when in my head I thought I should be happy that my only treatment was Mx.  You may already have seen the link to an article by Dr Peter Harvey that Little My gave to me, I know there are others on the site who have also been thankful for it.  Incase not here it is again www.cancercouselling.org.uk/northsouth/extra4.nsf/.../article3.pdf I was fortunate to have immediate reconstruction and for the most part I guess I'm happy with that, however there are days where I beat myself up about the difference in size and no amount of reassurance from anyone will convince me otherwise.  I have found that I feel this is less noticeable with a strappy bra top from www.amoena.co.uk.  I was introduced to them by my breast care nurse when I asked what to wear post surgery.  I now have a few colours and have used them dressed up to go on nights out or down with jeans, they are so comfortable. You and your partner have a lot to deal with and I'm sure he didn't mean to upset you.  I had a conversation with a friend who's husband has cancer, she told me that it is difficult for the partner to know what to say or do. Is lypo filling an option for WLE?  I'm not sure,,,, maybe others can help.  I know that there was a girl having this done when I was in hospital but didn't get to ask why. Once I was able to drive I took myself shopping and bought a dress with a lot going on up top which I felt boosted my confidence.  I wore this to a party at New Year and I can honestly say that those who didn't know porobably didn't guess. Take care
Posts.Title: Fed up and on a downer

Posts.Content: Annabel, Sending a huge HUG as I can't really say anything to comfort you other than, try to take inspiration from the people on this site who have overcome the obstacles you are faced with. I'm sure some of them will be along very soon with messages of encouragement. I've had a reconstruction and in the begining had the same feelings as you that everyone was staring, It took a while to realise that in reality that's not the case. I also was dreading warmer weather when I wouldn't be able to hide under a coat or jacket but can honestly say that I now happily walk about without either, albeit some days I do wish it wasn't so.I hope you have a lovely day, BBQ sounds just what we all need. Please don't feel you are a moaning Minnie, anything you need to get off your chest (if you'll pardon the expression) is not a moan but your mechanism for coping. That's why we are all on here. Take care
Posts.Title: fear of scan and first ONC appt

Posts.Content: So pleased for you Annabel, that really made my day. I'm sure the girls in the office wondered what I was grinning at.
Posts.Title: shrinking lump!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi girls, sorry to butt in here but that really did put a smile on my face and my tale may do the same for you. I'm feeling a bit down because I can't shake of this "cold virus".  If I was to update my satus today it would be "my get up and go has got up and went".  Smile? well it reminded me that one of the breast care nurses told me infront of my hubby that I wouldn't be able to do the ironing for a few weeks after my Mx only to continue with "infact Julie if there is anything you don't like doing tell me and I'll tell him you can't"  Seven months on hubby still does the ironing, bliss.... pity I didn't think to tell her about the bathroom. My thoughts and prayers are with you all as you move along on that rollercoaster. Take care
Posts.Title: bit of a meltdown

Posts.Content: Morning carriek, hope you've managed to get some sleep, decision times are always the worst. Love your JUST, I remember saying that if I just have a simple strattice recon at the same time as mx it will be one scar and one short recovery time. Then ....... panic when Breast Surgeon said he would do it all. I was reassured by my Breast Care Nurse that this was quite normal. BS was able to give me a date for surgery at that appointment without the need to liaise with the Plastics Team. He told me that I could always come back for a better match, however I'm only a B cup and although undressed I think they look odd, they're actually not bad once I'm in a bra. I've not shared this, for fear of blowing my cover but I was operated on in the hospital I work in. Sitting up in bed post surgery the Plastics guys all did a double take, seeing my Consultants initials they quickly realised why I was there. When I told them what procedure I'd had and that Mr B had done my reconstruction, there were nothing but favourable comments. One even said that's good it's all done and dusted. I had kind of felt guilty that they may have thought why hadn't I asked for one of them, but I needn't have worried. Hopefully throughout today there'll be lots more with the same procedure as you to help you make your decision for tomorrow. I guess in short I'm saying that in my experience the Plastic Surgeons had every confidence in the Breast Surgeons. All the best with your surgery and recovery whatever you decide. ladybird51 hope all goes well for you tomorrow. Virtual hand holding and hugs
Posts.Title: Anyone had Mx, reconstruction (LD - Back flap) and reduction in other...

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for that, Helen. I thought someone had to have already made a long haul trip. Flights are booked and so looking forward to seeing everyone, it's been over two years. I'm happy to hear the experiences of those who have already flown.
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: ...........but are they safe? I had Mx with strattice reconstruction way back in October 2011 and have finally plucked up courage to book flights to visit our son in USA. Feeling a bit apprehensive about the effects of cabin pressure on my reconstruction and would appreciate anyone sharing their experience with me. Thank you for reading and even though you may not be in a position to reply I sincerely wish you all the best with where this journey is taking you.
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: Hi Carrie, Apologies just a quick reply as I'm running late for work. If you want to pm me any specific questions I should be able to reply this evening. Yes, I had a strattice reconstruction, hence my title, sorry have to find some humour in it. I'm known to refer to my mismatched pair as pinky and perky. Since I'm small busted the size difference isn't so noticeable, it's more like one wobbles and one doesn't. It is still early days for you with lots more internal healing to do. It certainly does settle down, in terms of being hard although I find mine can change from day to day, I'm sure this is weather related though. Best check with your Consultant or BCN but I shouldn't think it will droop any further after six weeks, at least I don't think mine did. I'm sure they sit it at a position which looks alien undressed so that when in a bra they appear to be in the same position. On the whole I'm happy with my choice. Hope you have a good day
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: Thanks rosie52 so glad you had a brilliant holiday. Dubai seems to be a very popular destination these days. I've had a few friends and relatives holiday there and only ever heard good reports about it. Sadly, with a son living overseas our holiday of choice always draws us close to him, so might never get to see it. I know it's bad and I tell everyone else not to do it but I did google to check on expansion of silicone implants in flight and while some said they didn't others were scary. My son reminded me of all the jet set celebs who have reportedly had augmentation. Of course any problem they had would be all over the press. Too late to get in a flap now, flights are booked and I'm so looking forward to seeing everyone. Hope you have a good day.
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: Hi Gina Welcome to macland, where you will get lots of support. I'm sure someone will soon be along to help you with advice on Rads and Tamoxifen, sorry I can't, my only treatment was Mx. I've just popped in to say well done for joining us, I think most of us hover around in the beginning. I know I did, but am so grateful for the support from here. My BCN had told me about the site and I had had a look but it wasn't until four months down the line when the tears I thought I should have had durirng the time of diagnosis and treatment started to flow. You find out here that it is perfectly normal to stay positive and focus on what is happening at the time, wobbles come when most unexpected. I can empathise with the guilty feelings, I used to think I was mad to feel wobbly when I should be grateful that the removal of 'booby' was the end of my journey. Even almost a year on it all seems a bit surreal, I kept a journal at the time, even so I never quite lost the feeling that I was talking about someone else. I wish you well on this roallercoaster. Jules x
Posts.Title: "Another newbie".........

Posts.Content: Hi pretty in pink caught your question when checking emails in my lunch break yesterday but couldn't answer then. I've just had a check up with my Consultant where I struggled to undo the back of my bra so I jokingly said that sometimes that arm just didn't want to work.  I got the knowing look with the comment "your physio exercises will help with that"  My Mx and reconstruction was 20 months ago, so my guess is that they should be part of our life for evermore.  Incidentally, I did them religiously for the first three months but tailed off as I was back at work and doing normal everyday things. I do though at times of discomfort find myself going back to basics. Hope this helps Hugs and best wishes to you all
Posts.Title: Exercises for arm after reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi tokes, deep breaths, I know it's a really scary sight, I thought I was falling apart. If this is stitching from your scar you should check with your breast care team. I had no external stitching but not sure if that applies to everyone. My consultant told me that it was one of the internal disolving stitches. although goodness knows how they manage to work themselves through like they do. He said it was nothing to worry about although I thought it would never go away, like how was it going to disolve if it was on the outside. it took a good six months before I was no longer aware of it. Also if your seroma is really uncomfortable ask your team if you can have it drained. I had to have this done a few times but the relief was immense. Wish you well on the rocky road ahead.

Posts.Title: talking

Posts.Title: A bit of a weird one.....

Posts.Content: appreciate it may be a while before you read this message just wanted to say that I will be thinking of you tomorrow and hoping you emerge from surgery pleased with your decision. Gentle comforting hugs for when you need them most.
Posts.Title: Anxiety re mx and reconstruction
